title: Tony-winning Irish playwright Brian Friel, author of ‘Dancing at Lughnasa,’ dies at 86
text:
Posted Oct 2, 2015 6:44 am   2, 2015 at 7:40 am EDT FILE - This is a Sept. 11, 2009 file photo of playwright Brian Friel sitting in a theatre in Dublin. Authorities say Brian Friel, the Tony Award-winning playwright who created ``Dancing at Lughnasa’’ and more than 30 other plays, has died at the age of 86. The Arts Council of Ireland says in a statement that Friel died Friday Oct. 2, 2015. The cause of death was not given. (Niall Carson/PA , File via AP) 
DUBLIN – Irish authorities say Brian Friel, the Tony Award-winning playwright who created “Dancing at Lughnasa” and more than 30 other plays, has died at the age of 86. 
The Arts Council of Ireland says in a statement that Friel died Friday. The cause of death was not given. 
The statement says Frield “was, quite simply, a giant not only of Irish but of world theatre.” 
Trained as a teacher, Friel turned to writing plays full time after the international success of his debut 1964 play, “Philadelphia, Here I Come!” 
He collaborated with poet Seamus Heaney, actor Stephen Rea and fellow playwright Frank McGuinness in creating Ireland’s Field Day Theatre Company and produced its most celebrated work, “Translations,” in 1980.
